preface.title: Introduction
preface.para: This guide describes how to use XEditNetAuthor. XEditNetAuthor is a Windows desktop application that provides editing functionality for XML documents.

sect1.title: Audience
sect1.para: The intended audience for this guide is people editing XML content using XEditNetAuthor or the core component which is called XEditNetCtrl. Where appropriate the functionality specific to XEditNetAuthor is indicated in this document.
People interested in configuring XEditNet or building applications based on XEditNetCtrl should refer to the XEditNet Developer's Guide.

sect1.title: How this guide was produced
sect1.para: This guide was written using XEditNetAuthor according to the Docbook DTD and converted to Microsoft HTML Help using the Docbook XSL Stylesheets. The source for this guide is provided with the XEditNetAuthor distribution, under the samples/docbook directory. A simple script to produce the HTML Help is in samples/docbook/userguide/make.cmd.

sect1.title: Open an existing file
sect1.para: Select FileOpen (Ctrl-O) and browse to the file you want to open.
By default only XML files are shown but you can also filter for XHTML/HTML files or all files.

If the file references a DTD, XEditNet will attempt to open the file as a valid XML document. If this fails because of validation errors you can attempt to open the document as well-formed. When this happens XEditNet manually validates the document after opening which may take some time for very large documents.

sect1.title: Save the current file
sect1.para: Select FileSave (Ctrl-S) to save the current file. XEditNet will save the file without warning even if it contains validation errors.

sect1.title: Move around the document
sect1.para: XEditNet has a default set of shortcut keys for navigating the document. See for a full list of shortcut keys.

sect1.title: Select, cut copy and paste text
sect1.para: Use the standard keys such as ShiftRightArrow to select text, or drag select using the mouse. To quickly select the current element contents, select EditSelect Content (Ctrl+E). Repeat this action to progressively increase the selection upwards to the document element.
Cut, copy and paste using the Edit menu or the standard CtrlX, CtrlC, CtrlV key combinations.

You can also paste text from other applications. XEditNet first looks at the clipboard for content that was copied from XEditNet. It then attempts to parse the data as XML and import into the current document. If that fails but there is text on the clipboard it will paste the raw text into the current document.

sect1.title: Insert a new element
sect1.para: To insert a new element, select ContentInsert Element (Ctrl+I).
By default XEditNet displays elements that are valid in the current context. To show all elements in the DTD, uncheck Only Show Valid Items (Alt+V).

Elements that are required are shown with a red next to them. If an element is required but more than one option is available, these elements are shown with a green next to them (you must insert at least one of these elements).
Press Return to confirm, or Escape to cancel.
To filter items in the list, enter a partial element name. For example, a will match abbrev, acronym and so on. Enter a space after the name, such as "a " for an exact match.
If the document does not have a DTD, no elements are shown. To create a new element, enter the name of the element in the filter text box and press Return.

note.title: Valid elements list
note.para: XEditNet shows all elements that are are valid in the current context (that is, at the cursor). However it does not check that the content of the inserted element would be valid. This is intentional as it is the sensible action in most cases; for example, section elements often have required sub-elements which you typically insert after inserting the section. However, it can be a little confusing in some cases; for example, if you select some text or an element that is then invalid in the context of the inserted element.

sect1.title: Work with attributes
sect1.para: To edit element attributes, select ContentModify Attributes (Ctrl+L).
XEditNet displays all the existing and possible attributes for the current element. Attributes that are specified have a the icon next to them. Click this icon to remove an attribute.
Validation takes place as you type.
To add a new attribute, click the icon at the top of the window. Note that if the document has a DTD any added attributes not already in the list are automatically invalid.

sect1.title: Change an element name
sect1.para: To change the current element's name, select ContentChange Element (Ctrl+J). This provides a list of elements that are valid alternatives to the current element in the context of its parent. Note that all attributes are kept, and this can cause validation errors which will be shown when you press Enter. See for more information on the approach to validation.

sect1.title: Hide and show tags
sect1.para: To hide tags select ViewTags Off (Ctrl-K, Ctrl-O). To show them again, select ViewTags On (Ctrl-K, Ctrl-N).

Note that currently XEditNet is intended for use with tags on. The tags off mode is intended as a very simple preview mechanism. Cursor movement and selection is not quite as natural in tags off mode. This is because, when tags are hidden, no information is given about the possible insertion points between two runs of text.
